column1: The first male of English parents born in the current area of North Carolina was John Fulford. He was born in 1629 in what is now Carteret County. He settled in this area and died in 1729. An article dated Sept. 18
column3: in The New Bern Daily Journal
column4: identified Fulford's grave in a cemetery outside the county seat of Beaufort
column5: in an area called the Straits. It was described as "bricked up with English brick." In 1971 a survey by the Carteret County Historical Society found such a grave in the Fulford Cemetery off Piper Lane in Gloucester.  The unmarked
column6: bricked-up grave matching this description survives today.One of the more prominent families from Carteret County was the Dennis family. William Dennis Sr. (b.1720 - d.1800) was an extremely colorful landowner
column8: and defender of the county. In 1747
column9: he assisted with the successful defense of the county during the War of Jenkins' Ear (fighting against Spanish pirates). During the Revolutionary War he served as a 2nd Major in the Carteret County Regiment of the North Carolina militia. In 1782
column10: he fought alongside Lieutenant Colonel John Easton to drive the British from Carteret County.  Dennis once owned the Hammock House
column11: which became well known as the house owned by the pirate Blackbeard. His son
column12: William Dennis Junior was a Captain in the 8th North Carolina Regiment (1777-1778)
column13: was present at Valley Forge and also fought in the Carteret County Regiment (1781-1782). In the 1790 US Census
column14: Dennis was one of the largest land owners in the county. Branches of the Dennis family include the Bells
column16: many of whom continued to live in the area for many years. In a typical pattern of following the availability of new lands in the Deep South
column17: some branches of this family later migrated to Mississippi and Texas in the 19th century.

column1: Carteret County is a member of the regional Eastern Carolina Council of Governments.  It includes 16 of North Carolina's townships.
Carteret County operates under the Council-Manager form of Government in North Carolina. The County Manager is Tommy Burns.
A voting machine malfunction in the county resulted in the loss of 4
column2: 438 ballots cast during early voting for the November 2
column3: 2004 general election.  Since the number of lost ballots exceeded the lead held (by Steve Troxler over Britt Cobb) in the statewide race for agriculture commissioner
column4: the State Board of Elections decided to hold a special election on January 11

column1: Marine Corps Auxiliary Landing Field Bogue is located in the western section of Carteret County along Bouge Sound.  It comprises an 875 acres (3.54 km2) landing field located on Bogue Sound that serves as the Marine Corpsâ€™ only East Coast site for Field Carrier Landing Practice (FCLP).

column1: The county is served by the Carteret County Public Schools. Carteret County Public Schools has 16 schools ranging from pre-kindergarten to twelfth grade. Those 16 schools are separated into three high schools
column3: and nine elementary schools.In addition the county is home to a public charter school and three private schools:

column1: Tiller School is a grade K-5 public charter school in Beaufort
Saint Egbert School is a grade K-5 Catholic school in Morehead City
Grace Christian School is a grade K-8 school in Newport
Gramercy Christian School is a grade K-12 school in Newport

The Carteret County News-Times is a community newspaper based in Morehead City that serves Carteret County and nearby areas. Its predecessors were The Beaufort News
column3: and the Twin City Daily Times
column4: a newspaper founded in 1936. The Phillips family purchased and merged the two newspapers together to form Carteret County News-Times. The Carteret County News-Times's earliest printing was on May 18
column6: the newspaper has published three editions a week: Wednesday
column8: and Sunday. According to the 2010 book North Carolina's Central Coast and New Bern
column9: the newspaper is "a good source of information for vacationers who want to know the schedules of tours
column13: exhibits and events of all types within the county and the surrounding area".
